title: No, You DON'T Need a Single-Page App
body:
Are you and your team building a new product and expecting to make it a single-page application (SPA)?  Have you considered all the risks and hidden costs in making a SPA?
In this talk, you'll learn about when it's appropriate to build a single-page application, the downsides of going single-page too early, and the longer term tradeoffs you make once your application is a SPA.  You'll learn about accessibility, how your users interact with your applications using external tools, and the costs of solving these with SPAs.  The talk will also touch on security, code bloat, fragility, and testability of SPAs.  Then, you'll learn about some alternative solutions.
tags: javascript,spa

presenter.name: Penny Sheaffer
presenter.bio: Penny works at Pivotal Software, where they've spent the last four years working in different parts of the organization as an engineer, consultant, and solutions architect.  This is Penny's first conference, and they don't know what to say in a bio!

title: Building a Better Commonwealth Through Citizen Advocacy
body:
No one thinks about state government providing citizen-centric services and solutions that are couched in user research, but it's true. My team and I are creating those experiences for the State of Pennsylvania in collaboration with the Governor's Office to create governments services and products that are useful and meaningful to Pennsylvanians. By taking human centered design principles and putting them into practice with Governor Tom Wolf's initiatives, we helping to create a new relationship with citizens that will see state government as an ally.

What you'll learn from this presentation:
- Who we are and what we do for PA state government.
- How we implement design thinking to create better experiences.
- How we do research to make sure we're making services that matter to citizens.
- How we define and implement UX at the Commonwealth level.
- How to get involved and inform how to improve services.

This presentation is unique to Pennsylvania in a big way, but will give out of state attendees a way to reach out to their respective state governments. What attendees will get from this presentation is how the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania is shifting to a more human-centered approach and how we meet those challenges through our tools, processes and strategies.
tags: pennsylvania, user research, design, organization

presenter.name: Tim McKenna
presenter.bio: Tim McKenna is the Director of Experience Design at Pennsylvania Interactive LLC, part of NIC, Inc. at Pennsylvania Interactive, he leads a small team of designers, researchers, and developers in the creation and implementation of products and services that benefit Pennsylvanians everyday. He has over 13 years experience in the design field working in industries from healthcare, technology, artificial intelligence, student financial aid, and advertising. Tim is a past president of AIGA Central PA and Society of Design ad is a current member of InVision's Design Leadership Forum and IxDA. Originally from Pittsburgh, Tim lives in Carlisle, PA. Outside of design and family, Tim is an avid musician and homebrewer.

title: Designing More Ethical and Unbiased Experiences
body:
Humans are biased, and sadly, we are not always able to filter our deeply ingrained biases. UX designers and researchers have long understood this, but as we watch major technology companies make significant mistakes with regard to ethics and bias, the cost of not accounting for bias and ethics is becoming more evident and widely known.
 
In this session, we’ll share ways you can empower yourself and your teams to do the right thing for people. Even knowing what pitfalls exist, we still miss opportunities for doing good as a result of our own human biases obscuring our vision. We need tools to explore and challenge our biases in a productive way to deliver better outcomes. We need a set of shared values across all roles in software development and, ultimately, across the industry to promote our common responsibility to deliver the greatest benefit while causing the least amount of harm. How can we work together to intensify the focus on ethical design?
tags: ethics, bias, ethical design, inclusion, ai, data

presenter.name: Karen Bachmann
presenter.bio: Karen Bachmann has over 20 years of experience supporting clients in all phases of user-centered design. She has worked with clients in various industries including scholarly publishing, retail, insurance, technology, education, and energy. She uses a wide range of research techniques to explore and define problems thoroughly to help identify the best, holistic solutions that fit the organization's need. Karen regularly presents on research, design, and fundamental professional skills at international and regional professional conferences and to local business groups and meetups.

title: What Can a Service Mesh Do for You
body: As companies shift from monoliths to microservices, operations engineers are increasingly turning to a service mesh to achieve load balancing, mutual TLS, request tracing, service discovery, and observability in their highly available distributed systems. In this introduction to service meshes, we’ll explore the two leading tools in the space: Linkerd2 and Istio. Attendees will learn the differences between the two, and how both can be leveraged effectively with a minimal learning curve. When discussing the service meshes, our example microservice architecture will be running on Kubernetes, a brief overview of Kubernetes and microservices will be given as well to help all attendees grasp any concepts used.
tags: service mesh, istio, likerd2, microservices, kubernetes

presenter.name: Mike Stoltz
presenter.bio: Mike is a Software Engineer at Containership Inc. He has been working with containers and orchestrators for 3 years now, concentrating on Kubernetes for the last 2. He manages the microservice infrastructure of Containership using Kubernetes and was integral in the development of their cluster management platform and provisioning tool.

title: Improving Design through Test Driven Development
body:
There are numerous benefits to writing unit tests; they help with regression and provide executable documentation. However, there is yet another benefit that seems to go unnoticed. They facilitate good design!

In this session, we'll write a program not once, but twice. The first time we won't consider TDD at all. Next, we'll write the same program using TDD and see how different the two approaches truly are. Then we can ask ourselves, what had to change to make the program testable? What can we do now that the program has a suite of tests behind it?

If you want to see how leveraging test-driven development encourages a better design, this is the talk for you!
tags: testing, quality, tdd, unit testing

presenter.name: John Reese
presenter.bio: John Reese is a professional .NET developer and a Microsoft Certified Professional in C#. He is also an active open source contributor for Exercism, a learning platform used to teach test-driven development. In his free time, he enjoys playing hockey and video games, both of which he takes way too seriously.

title: That Time I Accidentally Built a Sweatshop
body:
When we build software we build experiences, and with that comes ethical responsibility. The poster child for these dilemmas might be variable reward consumer apps, but software for work is even worse! How often do your tools make you angry? How often do they dictate how you work and take away your professional autonomy?

In this talk I'll explore my experiences building software for the workplace, the ethical lessons I've learnt, and some of the hidden ethical problems in features of the software you use every day.
tags: ethics,saas

presenter.name: Matthew Owen
presenter.bio:
I'm a staff software engineer at Flexport, leading our collaboration platform team. Prior to that I worked on software supporting curated content at eBay, and before that as a software engineer at Twice, an intermediated marketplace for second hand clothing.

In a past life I was a PM at Torchbox working with NGOs and non-profits, and before that a literature student at the University of Oxford.

My daughter was born this year and I hope the future she grows up to is less dystopian than the present, not more.

title: Coding the Crossfade
body:
When Michael Winslow first decided to place 2 Windows Media Player controls onto a Visual Basic form in the early 2000s, he had no idea that it would lead to a fifteen year adventure as a DJ in Philly! But just like any other DJ, Winslow had to prove himself. All of the fancy tech he created would mean nothing if he could not keep the party moving during song transitions! The key to that: Coding the Crossfade!

Join me as I show some key functionality and data needed to make software crossfade like a real DJ!
tags: engineer development dj music crossfade

presenter.name: Michael Winslow
presenter.bio:
Michael Winslow picked up his love for programming when he was 10 years old writing GW-Basic code on his Tandy-1000. With his passion for designing simple solutions to complex problems, Michael has played key roles at companies like Aramark, Ortho-McNeil, Oracle and Xfinity Mobile. He is currently a DevOps advocate, Agile enthusiast, and dedicated people-leader for the Core Applications group at Comcast.

Speakerdeck:
https://speakerdeck.com/michaelswinslow/coding-the-crossfade

Prezi:
https://prezi.com/view/j7Gik3rq4WIfob3HaUl0/

title: Distractions
body:
- Pinball arcade
- Board games
- and much more!

title: Easy Peasy Accessibility
body:
In a recent audit of the accessibility of the top 1,000,000 home pages, 97.8% of home pages had detectable WCAG 2 failures. We can do better than this!

Let's take a deep dive into the low hanging fruit of accessibility so we can fix these issues once and for all. We'll go over auditing a site, interpreting the results and implementing solutions.

In this session, learn: 

*Some quick and easy 5 minute fixes you can do right now (contrast, fonts and :focus)
*A break down of the images, alt text and links
*Button vs link
*Common mistakes we make with semantics and roles
*How to handle forms
*What's new in WCAG 2.1
*Testing automation (break the cycle of inaccessibility)
tags: accessibility, building a better web, code for good

presenter.name: Heather Migliorisi
presenter.bio: As a Senior Software Engineer, Heather is responsible for implementing accessibility solutions for a international, multifaceted corporation on one hand while continuing to on building new features in the GiftCards.com site.

title: You (Yes, You) Need to Support Junior Developers
body:
"We just can't find all of the developers that we need to build our product"
"Here's a promising developer, right out of code school, why don't you hire her?"
"Oh, we don't hire junior developers. Because $REASONS."

Life as a new developer can be frustrating, especially for one coming out of something other than a big-name Computer Science program. They hear about the shortage of developers in the industry, but often find it extremely difficult to get that first job. However, if there are no junior developers, there will eventually be no senior developers. Frequently, companies do not know how to successfully integrate new developers, and the developers lack the experience and confidence to understand their needs. So how can your team be part of the solution?

In this session, you will hear from a longtime hiring manager/CTO, who has hired at all experience levels for remote and in-office development teams, and who has successfully onboard and supported entry-level developers at several companies. They will discuss several areas where teams stumble in effectively supporting new developers, and provide actionable techniques that your company can use to make the most of valuable talent out on the job market.

It's a cutthroat market for development talent out there. If your company can find and grow new developers when your competitors cannot, you will end up ahead of the game. Plus, you will be helping the future of the industry. Come learn how.

presenter.name: Wade Minter
presenter.bio: Wade Minter is the Chief Technology Officer for Custom Communications Inc, leading a team of Ruby software developers. He was previously in technology leadership at TeamSnap, Adwerx, and WeaveUp. He is also the arena public address announcer for the NHL's Carolina Hurricanes, a professional wrestling ring announcer, and an improv comedian. He leads a weird life.

title: The EM Kata
body:
Kata is the Japanese word for form.  In the martial arts, it is the series of forms and exercises necessary to support eventually mastery.  Many consider the practice of a given kata to be an individual pursuit, but true masters know that group practice and engagement is essential to true mastery. 

What makes a good engineering manager?  What makes a good manager great?  There are a growing number of tomes that explain the path one takes to becoming a manager, but what do you do once you get there?  In this talk, we will explore the exercises required to build the muscles necessary to continue your growth as a leader of people.  Specifically, we will discuss patterns to model, and anti-patterns that you should definitely avoid.  

We will explore the differences between mentoring, coaching, and sponsorship as the leader acts as both protege and adviser.  This talk will also explore the concept of secular humanist based servant leadership, and challenge the notion that the engineering leader is first a technical leader.  We will discuss humility as an asset, and stress on the importance of listening as the most essential path towards understanding.  

Finally, there will be code.  We will discuss how the code we use as leaders can often expose unconscious biases.  The practitioner must be ever aware of these potential blind spots as they continue to grow and share their knowledge with others.
tags: engineering leadership, management, bias, mentoring, coaching, sponsorship

presenter.name: Tramale Turner
presenter.bio: Tramale is an Engineering Manager at Stripe working to build the economic infrastructure of the internet.  Prior to Stripe, Tramale has held engineering leadership roles at companies such as F5 Networks and Nintendo, and technical and marketing leadership roles at Critical Mass and Volkswagen. He has a passion for developing technology leaders at all levels, and is determined to hear underrepresented voices amplified in our industry.

title: Non-Artificial Intelligence: Modelling Other Minds
body:
Do you want to learn to communicate better, but you don’t know how to? How about with a board game?

Hanabi is a cooperative game with hidden information where the players work together to solve a logic puzzle. Each player must both listen to and speak to other players, imagining what they know and think in order to make sense of the very limited communication that’s allowed. The players build models of each other’s minds by asking themselves questions like: What do I know? What does my partner expect? Why did they choose that move and not another one?

This talk will cover the basics of Hanabi and use a variety of gameplay puzzles to ask you to consider how they apply to communication in other domains, like work and relationships. You’ll walk away with new ideas about:
- Basing your assumptions and actions on the goals you share with your partners
- Considering multiple interpretations
- Building expectations and noticing when they’re not fulfilled
- Thinking about what your partner thinks you think

Finally, you’ll have learned how to play a truly spectacular board game. Come to the game room later to play Hanabi and communicate with others through this excellent medium!
tags: board games, communication, teamwork, fireworks

presenter.name: Jean Lange
presenter.bio: Jean Lange is really super into: smiling, learning about humans, enjoying the present moment. She likes colors and the daily crossword. She teaches at Academy Pittsburgh (https://academypgh.com/) and LFG (https://www.lfgpgh.com/) Board Game Night, but usually on different subjects.

title: What We Learned from Getting 100% of Our Engineers On-Call
body: This is a talk about scaling engineering culture, disguised as a talk about sustainable on-call rotations in the age of microservices. It is a report on Duolingo’s journey to an on-call ecosystem that includes every single one of our 80+ engineers and on the development of the “on-call pain balancer”, which automatically generates rotations based on team composition, service maturity, and incident statistics. We will share some of the tools and processes that have helped us reduce the burden of being on-call, and how setting out to standardize a single aspect of engineering life opened the door to a much deeper conversation and taught us lessons that went far beyond improving site reliability.
tags: on-call, microservices, scaling, engineering culture, work-life balance, documentation

presenter.name: Antonia Scheidel
presenter.bio: Antonia is a Senior Software Engineer at Duolingo, the most popular language-learning platform and the most downloaded education app in the world. She is currently working on building tools to help users take their language learning from the app into the real world and back again. Antonia has been the Tech Lead on several teams and loves building teams as much as building products.

title: Effective Engineering: Step Away from the Keyboard
body:
A lot of really good engineers make the same mistake: The path to being a better engineer is to “engineer harder”. Instead, engineers should focus on the holistic aspects of working effectively while solo and in teams. In this talk, i’ll cover the “other” skills engineers need, and how to grow them.

When trying to get ahead in your career or just improve as an engineer, time and time again people think the only solution is to either step into the management track, or double down and engineer as hard as they can. If only they can bang out slightly better code, they’ll be that better engineer.

But this a myopic and frankly incompatible approach with the realities of engineering in many companies. “The engineer in the corner” is not who you should aspire to be, and increasingly the opportunity to be such an engineer is disappearing. Even in the biggest companies, the lone wolf is a dying breed.

Instead, engineers should focus on what have incorrectly been labeled as “soft skills”, when in fact it’s really amongst the hardest things to be good at for almost all of us. Communication. Empathy. Collaboration. Problem Solving (and not just at the code level). Responsibility.

These are among the topics I will speak on from my 15+ years of industry experience, working in small and large companies, cross functionally across many different roles. The road to being seen as a leader doesn’t just go through ManagerTown, nor does it only pass through Brilliant Jerksburg. It’s a highway that anyone - lifelong ICs or managerial hopefuls alike, need to focus on as they level up in their career.

The goal of this talk to reinforce good practices amongst the audience when it comes to the aforementioned skill sets, and hopefully open the eyes of folks who so far might eschew such things as “not worth it”.
tags: leadership, engineering, soft skills is a stupid term and everyone needs to stop using it

presenter.name: Sean Kelly
presenter.bio:
I've been lucky enough to work across a number of industries in my 15 years in our field, including medical, energy, advertising, and as of late, security.

I was fortunate enough to marry a woman who was my best friend, and have been raising our dog and cat together.

I've been managing a team of 7 (and directing a wider group of nearly 20) for almost 2 years now, and it's given me an eye-opening perspective on all the ways I ruined the lives of my managers in prior jobs (I found one of them and gave him a hug once).

I love sleep but do not get enough of it.

title: Identity Expression: Coming Out of the Work Closet
body:
The phrase "coming out of the closet," has a ton of connotational baggage. In pop culture, coming out has been reserved for angsty teens, telling friends their big secret set to uplifting rock ballads. But in reality, coming out happens way more than once, including the workplace. What if I told you that most people, not just LGBTQ+ folks, may feel like they have to conceal part of themselves when they start their 9-to-5?

This talk will tackle the consequences and implications of identity concealment, and how that can hurt your bottom line and overall success in a company. Creativity, collaboration, productivity and communication are all directly tied to expression, so letting your employees and peers be themselves just makes good business sense.
tags: inclusion, diversity, lgbtq, minorities, equality, design, creativity, engineering, teamwork, culture, collaboration, community

presenter.name: Matthew Rogers
presenter.bio: As a recent grad and pseudo-grownup, my passion for engaging with others has mixed with a desire to make things. That power combo has manifested in a career in digital product design, a dedication to user research and experience, and a group of friends and family who wish I would stop talking about color theory so much.

title: Y2K Was a Feature: Accounting for Time in Software
body:
Time is a complex mechanism in programming. Whether you’re building a calendar app or a decentralized internet, time will likely play an unexpected role in your software.

Popular bugs like Y2K have brought a lot of attention to how easily software can overlook such a vital part of everyday life. These bugs may be fun anecdotes, but they illustrate how difficult it can be to successfully account for every edge case time presents. Why is time so hard to deal with? It goes much further than time zones, daylight savings, and leap years.

As product designers and developers, it is essential that we better understand the gap between user expectations and the realities of how time operates.

We’ll chronicle some time-related programming bugs and what we can learn from them (and laugh at ourselves a little). We’ll also cover how different languages handle time and some best practices for storing, retrieving, and presenting time. Lastly we’ll dive into the special cases to be aware of as we design and build our software.
tags: time, y2k, time zones, utc, daylight savings, leap years, parsing, javascript, ruby, mysql, postgresql, iso8601, apis

presenter.name: Brian Sewell
presenter.bio: Brian is an Engineer at Adwerx in Durham, North Carolina. Although he was born and raised in North Carolina, he welcomes all forms of barbecue. Outside of work, he is a husband, recently new father, and future olympic curling champion.

title: The Self-Care Project: Refactoring Life, Sharing Issues
body:
We all know about self-care in the abstract. That it's good for us to find work/life balance in an increasingly multi-tasked world. That it's something we all need to be doing more of. However in reality many of us don't pay attention until it's too late. We burn out under a burden of high expectations and low self-esteem. And we struggle to break the cycle of stress and sustain the path to recovery. 

This is a talk about my ongoing journey - from recognizing symptoms to proactively creating tools and design patterns to help me navigate the stresses that impact my physical and mental well-being. I will start by unpacking the science of stress and it's connection to self-esteem. I'll then share specific strategies I use to combat key issues in my life, and provide a broad design pattern that others can use to create their own self-care toolkits.

At the core, it is also a talk about belonging and thriving in an industry that celebrates "workism" and denigrates vulnerability. To underscore that no one is alone in this. And that only by sharing our stories, and normalizing these conversations, can we effect productive change that leads to happier people and healthier communities.
tags: self-care, stress, toolkit, design patterns

presenter.name: Nitya Narasimhan
presenter.bio:
Nitya Narasimhan is a PhD and Polyglot with over two decades of software research & development experience across industry, academia and startups. After a decade in research at Motorola, she worked as a software consultant, an adjunct faculty and an engineering lead at a startup before discovering her passion for community.

She recently joined the Cloud + AI Developer Relations team at Microsoft as a senior Program Manager, focused on empowering and amplifying community and technology across professional, startup and academic ecosystems. Follow her @nitya or connect with her at #in/nityan

title: Positive Sum, Building with Privacy as a Basic Need
body:
Personal data privacy is a hot-button item today. It can often seem overly burdensome for the software developer looking to change the world. Developers and designers may look at regulations and current trends in data privacy as negative impacts to product innovation.

This is the wrong lens by which we should look at this.

In this talk, Noble shares opportunities to innovate around the growth in data, the growth in regulations like the GDPR. He shares insights on human-centered design opportunities that can help both independent developer or an established corporation. He presents practical examples to minimize the data you collect and best practices on asking for data in software only when it provides value for the user.
tags: design, privacy by design, software ethics

presenter.name: Noble Ackerson
presenter.bio:
Noble is a Google Developers Expert for product strategy and a seasoned technical product director delivering vision camera, web and mobile technologies from abstract concepts to final products. He led the award-winning DC-based Augmented Reality for fitness startup, LynxFit, as Product Owner and Co-founder. 

Noble sits on the Alumni Leadership Board for the leading online education startup, Udacity. A member of the Alumni Board at his alma mater, Lynchburg College and acts as the Publicity Chair for Ubicomp and ISWC, two top-tier conferences for the internet of things and wearable technology. When Noble is not focused on product, he is mentoring underrepresented and aspiring developers, speaking at technology events, or spending time with his daughters.

title: Designing for Speech
body:
Speech technology (Speech Recognition, Natural Language Processing, Speech Generation, etc) has dramatically improved over the past several years, which lead to an explosion of speech-ready devices in the consumer space: phones, cars, gaming systems, home assistants, and even TV remotes. It seems like the wild west. 

What few people know, though, is that speech technology has been successfully used in healthcare industry for several decades now.

I believe that Abstractions attendees can benefit from understanding the fundamentals of speech technology, what it is and is not well suited for, how to design, prototype, and test for it, etc. 

In his talk, I will cover a brief history of the technology itself and focus on outlining design principles for voice user interfaces (VUIs). I will illustrate my points with examples from my own work at M*Modal, including some dramatic mistakes along the way.
tags: design, ux, vui, speech technology, healthcare

title: Pedagogy in Pairing
body:
What do you do when a new developer joins your delivery team? What do they need to know to get up to speed? How do you begin to build trust? How does your approach change when working with a junior developer versus someone with a lot of general experience who's new to your specific project? 

For many of us, the answer involves a lot of pairing. But how can you make the most of it?

In this session, you'll learn to teach as you pair in an effective and inclusive way. We'll focus on the five Standards of Effective Pedagogy and Learning as a model for an excellent pair.
tags: pairing, inclusion, teamwork, knowledge transfer, soft skills

presenter.name: Aisha Blake
presenter.bio: Aisha Blake has a deep love for the tech community in Detroit. She has taught web development to people of all ages in bootcamps, workshops, and online courses. She currently works as an Application Developer for Detroit Labs. She is down for anything as long as there are puppies and/or karaoke involved.

title: Consider the Pattern
body:
Software design is hard. That’s why we invented design patterns. Design patterns abstract common approaches to problem solving into generic approaches that can be modified to suit the application at hand.

Many of the design patterns in common use today are inspired by static object-oriented Enterprise languages like Java and C++. These languages have a feature set that is somewhat more restrictive than the languages that came after them, and many design patterns are built to provide elegant ways around these restrictions.

Design patterns, like Dependency Injection, and the Singleton pattern arise from restrictions on how you can pass code around at runtime. The Visitor Pattern arose from a need to safely traverse data structures. Other patterns, like Iterators and Factories, have been replaced by first-class language features of their own.

In this talk, we’ll build up several design patterns, and then look at features in newer languages, and newer versions of languages that make each pattern unnecessary. In doing so, you’ll get a view into idiomatically designing code in your favourite language, and a greater understanding of design decisions users of other languages need to make.
tags: python, kotlin, java, design patterns, patterns, object-oriented programming, programming, architecture

title: Ready for Takeoff: The Journey from On-Premises to the Cloud
body: Innovating in a compartmentalized on-premises environment isn’t impossible, but in today’s need-for-speed-workspaces it’s limiting, and things quickly become overburdened. This rings especially true in large organizations as more people and more data weigh things down. This presentation explores the journey of UPMC Enterprises’ adoption of a fail-fast-develop-rapidly mindset, and the pains and gains associated with taking a 250+ person team and their projects to the cloud. From the early days of building core competencies, to standardizing technologies and services, to the evolution of DevOps in the cloud, there’s been a little turbulence – but much more success – so buckle your seatbelt, put your electronic devices in airplane mode, and enjoy the ride.
tags: aws, cloud, devops, automation, security

title: Overcoming Challenges: An Attitude of Iteration
body: Challenges are a very real part of daily life. Some challenges are very apparent, like having one finger on each hand. Other challenges, are less apparent but no less of a hurdle that must be jumped. As someone who was born different and has been challenged through life, I have a very interesting view on hitting challenges head on. I also like to laugh as I deal with these challenges. In this session I we will joke our way through having an attitude of iteration in how we deal with challenges in our personal lives AND in our work lives. Prepare to laugh, commiserate, and face your challenges!
tags: challenges, laughter, comedy

presenter.name: Eric Johnson
presenter.bio: I am a Senior Developer Advocate – Serverless for AWS. My passion is to help other developers embrace the Serverless revolution by escaping the ordinary of server management, and performing the extraordinary through code. I am a sucker for best practices in the serverless world and get giddy when I get a chance to teach others. In my free time, I love relaxing with my beautiful bride and five kids, yes you read right, five. I also fancy myself as a musician, well, at least a drummer.

title: Ethical Software: How Not to Build Bombs in the Modern Era
body:
"I made one great mistake in my life - when I signed the letter to President Roosevelt recommending that atom bombs be made" --Albert Einstein, 6 Nov. 1954

Ethics. It's a complex discipline, and it's rarely as clean cut in the moment as it seems when looking back through the lens of history. So what can you do to ensure your company isn't building bombs? How can you ensure your organization is trying to make ethical choices? Is it ethical to ask engineers to work 80 hours a week during their on call rotations? Is it sustainable? What about the contract the sales team just signed which promises a fully functioning product, from scratch, in less than six months? What do you do when you realize your app is leaking unencrypted data?

In this talk, I'll walk you through some of processes that my company has around ethical sales, sustainable workflows, and preventing burnout. I'll talk about what's worked for us & what hasn't-- from surfacing and discussing ethical concerns to ensuring our development process is sustainable -- both for our employees during a contract's term and for our clients after we hand off the finished product.
tags: ethics, building process around ethics, what works, what didn't work for us, sustainable engineering, ethical engineering, ethical software, ethical sales

presenter.name: Jeri Sommers
presenter.bio:
Jeri is a software engineer who graduated from Ada Developers Academy back in 2015. Since then, they have spent a few years working at Microsoft before leaving to join Truss, a software consultancy that has put a *lot* of thought into ethical processes.

Jeri is passionate about ethical software. Case in point: she left Microsoft over their relationship with ICE and joined Truss after asking a lot of questions about how they evaluated incoming contracts.

title: Using Accessibility as a Bridge Between Design & Development
body:
Web Accessibility is a team effort, but too often it is just viewed as a technical requirement relying only on the engineering team.
Unfortunately, you cannot deliver an accessible experience if the design and the project itself was not prepared for it.
In my last projects, I tried to use Web accessibility as a bridge between design & development and it worked.
New workflows, new deliverables, new rituals: focusing on making an accessible platform allowed my teams to abolish every wall between each specialties.
Let’s discuss together how we were able to do it and how we documented accessibility and shared accountability between PO, designers and engineers.
tags: accessibility, collaboration, team work, design, front-end engineering

presenter.name: Damien Senger
presenter.bio:
I’m a queer Design systems & Accessibility lead working in the healthcare industry for Castor EDC. Speaker, teacher and passionate about too many things, I am fighting every day for a more inclusive web.

Through my different projects, I am trying to make the Web a more inclusive and accessible place, while focusing on collaboration and mentoring. By the way, I’m agender, so my pronouns are they/them.

title: A Bug's Life: What If `Select` Is Broken After All?
body:
Your project's issue list lies dormant for months, years even. Users seem happy enough, and you've got other priorities. Suddenly, a flurry of users report a crazy-sounding bug. They're seeing a crash, triggered with specific keystrokes, with a common operating system. You can't reproduce it. What in the world?!

You may have heard the debugging tip from the fantastic book Pragmatic Programmer, "select isn't broken". It's always best to assume that bugs are in *your* code. But... what if this one isn't?

In this talk, you'll re-experience this unusual low-level bug, and take away some lessons for the kinds of debugging we need to do all the time as software developers.
tags: oss, jvm, clojure, linux

presenter.name: Colin Jones
presenter.bio: Colin Jones is CTO at 8th Light, where he works with teams to craft reliable, maintainable software. He's into application performance, security, DevOps, architecture, and functional programming. He once wrote a book about Clojure macros that mostly advises you not to use them.

title: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Primer
body: Cross-site scripting (XSS) is a code injection attack that allows an attacker to execute malicious JavaScript in another user's browser. The attacker's primary target are other users of an application.  XSS scripting is frequently exploited for illegitimate ad injection including click fraud, exploitation frameworks (such as BeEF) to attack the victim’s system from within the browser context, and bitcoin mining. This talk will demonstrate how various forms of these attacks succeed and what web developers can do to prevent them using input validation, Content Security Policy (CSP), and the Trusted Types experimental API.
tags: cross-site scripting, xss, content security policy, trusted types, secure web development, software security

presenter.name: Robert C. Seacord
presenter.bio: Robert C. Seacord is a Technical Director at NCC Group and works with software developers and software development organizations to eliminate vulnerabilities resulting from coding errors before they are deployed. Previously, Seacord led the secure coding initiative in the CERT Division of Carnegie Mellon University’s Software Engineering Institute (SEI). Seacord is also an adjunct professor in the School of Computer Science and the Information Networking Institute at Carnegie Mellon University. Seacord is the author of six books, including The CERT C Coding Standard, Second Edition (Addison-Wesley, 2014) Secure Coding in C and C++, Second Edition (Addison-Wesley, 2013), and Java Coding Guidelines: 75 Recommendations for Reliable and Secure Programs (Addison-Wesley, 2014). Seacord is on the Advisory Board for the Linux Foundation and an expert on the ISO/IEC JTC1/SC22/WG14 international standardization working group for the C programming language.

title: Innovating Security in Innovative Organizations
body:
Do you need to secure your leading technology product and business? Are
you struggling with aligning your security program to agile and devops?
Organizations can be compliant and secure while remaining innovative.
This presentation explores innovative processes and practices for
evolving traditional security controls. With these techniques, you can
securely enable the speed of change needed to disrupt in today's market
place. Warner will explore alternative methods using real world examples
for addressing security controls such as separation of duties, change
control, and release management using automation and modern practices.
tags: security, devsecops, infosec, devops, innovation, grc

presenter.name: Warner Moore
presenter.bio:
Warner Moore is a strategic technology leader and manager with a background in web operations and information security. He has focused his career in working with entrepreneurial growth organizations where technology is their business and product. Within these organizations, Warner has an accomplished record of building successful cybersecurity programs and high performing technology teams who embrace DevOps culture and practices.  

As an international speaker, Warner has been invited to present to university students, technology professionals, and business leaders in a classroom setting as well as at conferences such as Startup Week, CloudDevelop, Path to Agility,  InfoSec Summit, CodeMash, Security BSides, and DevOpsDays.

Warner is passionate about culture, innovation, and community. His passion reflects in his non-profit work with organizations such as Ohio LinuxFest, LOPSA, DevOpsDays, and Toastmasters. Recently, he founded a strategy consulting company that provides virtual CISO, CIO, and CTO services. Additionally, Warner advises and helps build startups.

title: Using AI to Build More Secure Software
body: MITRE's growing Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) list -- nearly 150,000 and growing -- is testament that building software that is resistant and resilient to attack remains difficult. The introduction of SecDevOps looks to improve security of software but has not taken advantage of how artificial intelligence could be used to improve the security of software. This presentation will discuss why the construction of secure software is a concern beyond the IT industry, the elements of a secure software development process and how artificial intelligence could be applied to improve that process. The discussion will then consider additional security issues facing the construction of artificial intelligence software.

presenter.name: Mark Sherman
presenter.bio: Dr. Mark Sherman is the Technical Director of the Cyber Security Foundations group at CERT within CMU’s Software Engineering Institute. His team focuses on foundational research on the life cycle for building secure software and on data analytics in cyber security. Before coming to CERT, Dr. Sherman was at IBM and various startups, working on mobile systems, integrated hardware-software appliances, transaction processing, languages and compilers, virtualization, network protocols and databases. Dr. Sherman received his undergraduate degrees from MIT and his PhD in Computer Science from CMU. He has published over 50 papers and several books on various topics in computer science.

title: The Differences and Benefits of Teaching High School Comp Sci
body:
How did you learn to code? Chances are it was not in high school. Only 35% of high schools teach computer science in the country. Yet computing jobs are the number one source of new wages, and the US has roughly 500,000 open positions. So how we can help solve this problem?

TEALS is one organization dedicated to bringing Computer Science to every high school. They connect tech professionals to high schools in need, who assist in CS education. But teaching in a high school environment is different than mentoring a junior engineer. 

This talk will dive into how you can volunteer, learn to teach, and teach to learn. As a bonus, we will also discuss how students can learn source control, and share their work with the world.
tags: education, teaching, mentoring, computer science, diversity, communication

presenter.name: Zackary Whipkey
presenter.bio:
Zack Whipkey is a software developer currently residing in Austin, TX. He lived in Pennsylvania for 25 years, and Pittsburgh for three years. As a TEALS volunteer this past year, he has been stationed an Austin High School in an AP Computer Science class.  He has worked across many stacks of software, industries, and has particular interests in education and security. You can read more about him at his blog: 

https://zdware.com/

title: Beyond the Sunset: How to Wring the Maximum Joy from Your Last 10 Years in Tech
body:
You’ve survived the internship, the seven year itch to switch careers, the mid-career management vs tech decision, and also mainframes, the Y2K panic, the dot-com boom, the Great Recession, the Java vs C++ wars, the birth of CSS and React/Redux, and that weird thing with bitcoin. It’s time to start thinking about retirement. 

But first, you need to think about how to enjoy your last 10 years or so in the tech industry. In this talk, I will lay out why this is the best phase of your career (because it really is), how to enjoy it as much as possible, and why you need to make a plan for what comes after.

presenter.name: Vanessa Kristoff
presenter.bio: Vanessa Kristoff has been a software engineer since the 1980s, and attributes her longevity in the industry to the fact that she prioritizes having fun at work.

title: Using Ansible and Terraform to Avoid Cloud Lock-In
body: One of the main pitfalls of moving to the cloud is locking yourself in to a particular provider.  Tools like CloudFormation can rapidly provision environments for your applications but make moving your infrastructure to a a different provider or your own infrastructure a complex process.  Come hear about using Open Source automation tooling to make your workloads easily portable across both public and private clouds with a minimum of reconfiguration.  The demo will focus using Ansible and Terraform to deploy to both AWS and VMware vCloud Director environments but the best practices discussed will apply to just about any combination of tooling and infrastructure that makes sense for your application.
tags: automation, aws, vmware, ansible, terraform, vcloud director

presenter.name: Mike Garuccio
presenter.bio: I am a product development engineer working for Expedient (https://www.expedient.com/) with a focus on our automated infrastructure management and Kubernetes products.

title: I'm Not Perfect (And I Know I Never Will Be)
body: When I transitioned into a tech lead role for the first time, I was terrified of the fact that I was expected to not be perfect from the beginning. Instead of trying to prevent the inevitable mistakes I would make, I had to change my perspective to focus on what I could control. In this talk, I’ll share concrete examples of how I lowered my anxiety around messing up in my new role and turned my blunders into learning opportunities.
tags: leadership, development, process

presenter.name: Sharell Bryant
presenter.bio: Sharell Bryant is a senior software engineer at Teachers Pay Teachers, an educational marketplace used by more than 2 out of 3 educators in the US. At TpT, Sharell is the tech lead of the Web Platform team helping support product engineering on the frontend. Outside of the office, you can find her out for a run in the park or playing guitar at an open mic.

title: Mind the Gap: Closing the Digital Divide in America
body:
According to the FCC, in Detroit - my hometown - 40 percent of residents do not have internet access of any kind at home, while 57 percent rely on their smartphones to get online. This is not exclusive to Detroit. Major cities across America like Miami, FL, Dallas, TX, Milwaukee, WI and Newark, NJ all have a population of 40 percent or more that does not have fixed broadband internet access at home. 

What challenges do people without Internet access face? What limitations do people with mobile-only Internet access encounter? As technology (and our relationship with it) continues to evolve, how can we better serve those who fall into the gaps of the Digital Divide?

In this talk, I will discuss some of the grassroots efforts in Detroit which seek to address the yawning chasm that separates those who can readily access technology and information from those who cannot. I will draw on my experiences working with nonprofit tech education organizations and programs. Together, we will see what this divide looks like and how we can help close this gap.
tags: tech literacy, digital divide, accessibility

presenter.name: Stephanie Vaughn
presenter.bio: After being adopted by Chicago for 14 years, Stephanie hit 'RESET' and returned to her hometown of Detroit in 2015 to reboot her writing ambitions into a tech career. This bold move has since yielded a foray into Computer Science education and working closely with nationally recognized groups like Black Girls Code. With over a decade of experience in media-focused Communications, the Grand Circus (Javascript, '16) and Integrate Detroit (Software Development, ‘18) alumna is always looking to share her passion for the T in “STEM” with developers & non-developers alike.

title: Oops–I guess we're full-stack developers now
body: A few years ago we were front-end developers. These days, as the tools we use to build the web are getting better, easier, and more powerful, we've suddenly become full-stack developers. Let's take a look at what happened and how we can take full advantage of our new super powers.

title: Artistic Style Transfer with Convolutional Neural Networks
body:
Style transfer is a technique for creating computer-generated art that powers apps like Prisma. It repurposes neural networks to combine famous paintings and photos to produce pastiches that mimic the artistic style. 

In this talk, we’ll take a look at the ideas behind this surprisingly simple algorithm and introduce fundamental Machine Learning and Deep Learning concepts along the way. Topics will include:

• A high-level introduction to neural networks and deep convolutional nets for Computer Vision.
• An overview of the original style transfer algorithm and related concepts like optimization.
• A review of new ‘fast’ architectures for running style transfer in real-time.
• Resources for learning more about ML/DL and Computer Vision.
tags: machine learning, deep learning, computer vision, computer-generated art

title: Unit Testing in Sass
body:
Remember that time someone on your team removed some questionable Sass, only to result in a broken UI? If this scenario sounds familiar, then Sass unit testing is for you! In this session, you’ll learn how unit testing is applied to Sass, how it can benefit your large project, and how to set it up in your own codebase. General takeaways will also include unit testing best practices and how to determine if your project is a good candidate for Sass unit testing. Lindsey will share her experience of unit testing an enterprise-level design system and how it has prevented unexpected UI changes. 

Consider this session if:
- You work on large projects heavily relying on a consistent UI, such as a design system
- You are passionate about code quality and testing
- You’ve worked with unit testing before and you’re curious to know how it could translate into a styling language
tags: unit testing, css, scss, sass, software quality

presenter.name: Lindsey Wild
presenter.bio: Lindsey Wild is a full-stack developer at Sparkbox’s Pittsburgh office. She’s worked on projects including an enterprise-level design system, various e-commerce websites, and dynamic web applications. She’s held developer positions for companies including DICK’S Sporting Goods and Giant Eagle and has more than six years of front-end development experience. In her free time, you can catch her on the volleyball court, watching a rock concert, or cheering on the Cleveland Indians.

title: UX Tools for Developers
body:
User experience and design are often hard problems for developers. We focus on code and hopefully someone else will make sure it looks good and users enjoy using it. That’s because user experience requires a different set of tools and thought processes. Sometimes, however, we do not have the luxury of a design team on every project. Add some of these tools to your toolbox so that every product you work on from this point forward has the extra edge. Regardless of if you are building an AR/VR, ML, or Mobile/Web app, this talk will help you to:

* Perform User Research
* Use sketching sessions 
* Affinity diagramming
* Design Information Architecture
* Create Valuable Personas
* Create User Journeys and Story Mapping
* Usability Testing
* Define Minimum Marketable Product
tags: user experience, personas, user research, sketching, mvp

presenter.name: Heather Shockney
presenter.bio:
Software development lead and team builder with experience in many languages, frameworks, and development processes. Project delivery using Ruby, Java, JavaScript, Swift, PHP, HTML, CSS, and SQL deployed to cloud environments including server-less. 

Managed and mentored team consisting of twelve full stack developers in a continuous learning organization. For the past two years, I have worked remotely for teams and clients located throughout the United States. 

Led front end portfolio delivery at Mined Minds, a software consultancy. Used UXD training and development experience to bring user research, persona building, affinity mapping, sketching, MVP defining, as well as frontend development coding skills to both consultancy and training organizations.

In my spare time, I love taking photos, kayaking,  and scary movies.

title: How Live Coding Changed My Life
body:
I have been live coding nearly every weekday for over a year for freeCodeCamp. It has changed my live. My fear of others seeing my code is gone. My skills as a dev have increased at a remarkable rate. Most importantly and unexpectedly, a caring and helpful community has developed.

How do you get over a fear of others seeing your code? Start live coding on YouTube of course!

Follow me on my journey from being a solo dev who was afraid of showing my code to anyone to live coding on a YouTube channel of nearly 300k subscribers. Along the way my skills improved dramatically. An amazing community of developers of all ages, locations, and skill levels has grown around the live streams. Live coding has changed my live as a developer and as a person, and I think anyone can enjoy the benefits of live coding.
tags: live coding, community building, learning, professional development

title: Bringing Order to Chaos: Incident Management and Your Organization
body:
How well did you handle your company's last major system outage or service degradation? What did you do when you discovered an internal system or process was broken and you needed to fix it ASAP? If your company is like most, episodes like these trigger organizational panic and uncertainty about the best response. This is why you need organized incident management.

In this talk, you'll learn why Incident Management should be part of every organization's framework for handling emergent issues of all kinds. You'll walk away with a solid understanding of how you can approach your company's next technology or business crisis in a more productive and time-efficient way. Fundamentally, you'll learn the process for dealing with challenges for which there is no process.
tags: incident management, operations, leadership, trust

presenter.name: Joshua Kaderlan
presenter.bio: Josh Kaderlan has worked in a wide variety of organizations and roles, from startups to Fortune 500 companies. He has more than 20 years of industry experience and calls the Bay Area home.

title: The Four Components of High-Performing Teams
body:
Do you have a great team & a great mission but don't understand why the pace of delivery is so slow? Architecture & tech stack is only one part of the story.
I believe high performing teams need four things to be effective:
Mastery - The skills & knowledge needed to do a great job, and a clear path to get to the next level.
Autonomy - The space to figure out their own solution to a problem & how they want to work
Purpose - A clear sense of direction, and the knowledge of how what they’re working on fits into the big picture & helps their team succeed.
Safety - A team that is afraid won’t take risks or experiment, a team that is afraid of finger-pointing won’t learn from mistakes.
In this talk I’ll explain why those four things are key to teams being successful and give examples of how I’ve turned teams around by fixing the lack of one or more of them.
tags: high performing teams, management, leadership

presenter.name: Lisa van Gelder
presenter.bio: Lisa has been in software for over 19 years, working in a wide range of companies from early stage startups to large media companies like the BBC & the Guardian newspaper. She used to debug code, now she debugs teams for a living. Lisa is currently VP, Engineering at Meetup. She is mostly powered by coffee.

title: You're Better at CSS Than You Think
body:
A few months ago in a spontaneous research project, I decided to scrape the top 10,000 most visited websites on the internet to look at their CSS.

This talk is a breakdown of what I found (spoiler - not all of it was good).

This is for all the developers who have ever said "I'm (adverb) bad at CSS", thought it, or heard someone else say it. What does it mean to be "good at CSS"? When is 'float' a good idea, or is it? How much should browsers dictate what we can use?

Let's find out!
tags: css, scss, sass, js, responsive, best practices

presenter.name: Thomas Golden
presenter.bio:
Tom Golden is a software engineer who works for Hatched Labs in San Francisco.

He moved from England to Silicon Valley three years ago with a degree in Discrete Mathematics, where he has worked for some hot start-ups, including Shipt where he was hired to be their first web developer.

He has a profound affection for all things CSS and design.

title: Taking Our JavaScript SDK Offline
body: Every day at Findaway, AudioEngine delivers millions of hours of audiobooks to listeners all over the world. We work with all the top players in the industry, including Audible, Apple, Google, Kobo, Scribd, and more. Our SDK helps dozens of apps deliver audiobooks to millions of listeners. But what if they don’t have an internet connection? Our native mobile apps allow for offline playback, why not our Javascript SDK too? Learn how we used modern browser capabilities to enable offline web playback into the AudioEngine Javascript SDK.
tags: front-end, javascript, audiobooks, offline

presenter.name: Cameron Wardzala
presenter.bio: Cameron Wardzala is a web developer at Findaway, with nearly 20 years of experience in front-end development. He has developed sites for brands like HH Gregg, I Can Has Cheezburger, and Vonage. For the past 5 years, he's focused on building audiobook technology for Findaway, including an e-commerce platform, an audiobook delivery SDK, and countless internal tools. He has spoken at local meetups and larger conferences in and around Ohio.

title: Conway's Law in Practice: Lessons Learned Building a Distributed Storage System and Team
body:
Conway's Law states: Any organization that designs a system (defined broadly) will produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization's communication structure.

With Conway's Law in hand, what should the team structure be for an open source project, aiming to build the world's largest decentralized cloud object storage system? 

This talk will take the audience through the engineering, communication and leadership lessons learned while growing a geographically distributed, diverse, engineering team. The goal of this talk is to provide everyone, regardless of their team structure, practical advice on how they can utilize Conway's law to improve communication and efficiency in their organization.
tags: engineering leadership, hiring, communication, distributed systems, decentralization

title: Code a Synth in 5 Lines (Of Your Code)
body:
Inspired by XKCD's "import antigravity", this talk aims to make programming "fun again" by leveraging Python and a handful of libraries to make a programmable synthesizer in an incredibly small amount of code.

From scratch, we'll explore the basics of digital audio synthesis, dive into NumPy's "broadcasting" features, and find ways to make our computers make really weird noises, with an emphasis on how very simple, clear code can lead to surprisingly complex results.

Cover image uses assets from: By Chrisjohnson, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=23282431
tags: music,python,generative art,how to

presenter.name: Remy Porter
presenter.bio: Remy Porter is a "creative coder" who mainly works on large-scale art installations, mixing digital technology with sculpture. As the Editor-in-Chief at TheDailyWTF.com, he's an expert in what makes bad code and bad workplaces, and writing articles about them. In addition to writing, Remy dabbles in film, theater, improvised comedy, and music, and is passionate about combining all of those interests into a single process.

title: Debugging Our Feelings: Cognitive Behavioural Therapy for Developers
body:
Developers have countless frameworks and tools to tackle technical problems but what can we use when we face personal ones? This talk is an introduction to cognitive behavioural therapy, which provides practical techniques to help change how we feel by changing how we think.

Through simple programming analogies, you'll learn:

1) What cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) is
2) Why the model it offers fits so well with our developer mindset
3) How CBT can be applied to help deal with challenges like procrastination, perfectionism, impostor syndrome, and handling criticism
4) How to turn a piece of paper into a powerful debugger for our thoughts
tags: mental health, self-care, cognitive behavioural therapy, procrastination, perfectionism, impostor syndrome

presenter.name: Jamie Strachan
presenter.bio: Jamie currently manages a team of developers at Loopio after spending 15 years as a web developer himself. He's (mostly) traded in coding for coaching and strives to help the developers around him be as effective as possible by being a facilitator, an advocate, and an advisor. He also shares his experience with depression to help combat the stigma surrounding mental health issues.

title: Evolving Ingress/v1beta1
body:
The Ingress object was added to Kubernetes in version 1.2 to describe properties of a cluster-wide reverse HTTP proxy. Since that time, it has not progressed beyond the beta stage, and its stagnation inspired an explosion of annotations to express missing properties of HTTP routing. 

In order to support a real-world ingress platform, a new Ingress CRD, named IngressRoute, aims to solve these missing properties as well as support multi-team clusters with the ability to limit the management of routes to specific virtual hosts. This delegation pattern allows for powerful ingress traffic manipulation across teams and reduces errors due to bad configuration.

Come see how a fresh perspective to ingress traffic can allow your teams to self-manage their application connectivity; as well as have a fully featured API spec to code against.
tags: kubernetes, devops, application deployments

presenter.name: Steve Sloka
presenter.bio: Steve Sloka is a Sr. Member of Technical Staff from Pittsburgh, PA currently working at VMware dealing with all things Cloud, Containers, and Kubernetes. Steve is a maintainer of Contour, Gimbal, the Elasticsearch Operator and is a contributor to many other open source projects. Steve is also a Kubernetes contributor and has been working with it since early 2015.

title: Introduction to Face Processing with Computer Vision
body:
Ever wonder how Facebook’s facial recognition or Snapchat’s filters work?

Faces are a fundamental piece of photography, and building applications around them has never been easier with open-source libraries and pre-trained models.

In this talk, we’ll help you understand some of the computer vision and machine learning techniques behind these applications. Then, we’ll use this knowledge to develop our own prototypes to tackle tasks such as face detection (e.g. digital cameras), recognition (e.g. Facebook Photos), classification (e.g. identifying emotions), manipulation (e.g. Snapchat filters), and more.
tags: artificial intelligence, data science, machine learning, computer vision, python, facial recognition, face processing

presenter.name: Gabriel Bianconi
presenter.bio:
Gabriel is the founder of Scalar Research, a full-service artificial intelligence & data science consulting firm. Scalar helps companies tackle complex business challenges with data-driven solutions leveraging cutting-edge machine learning and advanced analytics.

Previously, Gabriel was a B.S. & M.S. student in computer science at Stanford, where he conducted research on computer vision, deep learning, and quantum computing. He's also spent time at Google, Facebook, startups, and investment firms.

title: Humane Design Patterns
body:
The rapid growth of mobile technology has ushered in an age where time and attention is an increasingly scarce resource. Instead of technology enhancing our abilities as humans, we’ve seen it become a vehicle for extracting our attention, monetizing our personal information, and exploiting our psychological vulnerabilities. Designers and developers play a key role in the creation of such technology, and it’s time we take responsibility for the impact that these products and services we build are having on people it should serve.

In this session we’ll explore some common extractive design patterns in addition to alternatives that focus on user well-being instead. These patterns will be framed through the lens of guiding principles to follow when designing ethically humane products and services.
tags: UX, Design Patterns, Ethics

title: Closing Keynote
Departing High Fives
